timeline.bodyText: please explain why https://www.archunit.org/userguide/html/000_Index.html#_ignoring_violations does not work for us.
timeline.author: romani

replies.bodyText:
@romani I used breakpoints in the archunit code corresponding to this feature.
The FailureMessages are of the type:
java.lang.AssertionError: Architecture Violation [Priority: MEDIUM] - Rule 'slices matching 'com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.(**)..' should be free of cycles' was violated (13 times):
Cycle detected: Slice api -> Slice checks.naming -> Slice api
Dependencies of Slice api
Method <com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.api.AutomaticBean$RelaxedAccessModifierArrayConverter.convert(java.lang.Class, java.lang.Object)> calls method <com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.naming.AccessModifier.getInstance(java.lang.String)> in (AutomaticBean.java:398)
Dependencies of Slice checks.naming
Method 1....
Class 1....
Cycle detected: Slice api -> Slice checks.desgin -> Slice api
Method 1 ....
Method 2 ....
.
.
.

Here each section starting with Cycle detected: are treated as a single message in their filtering code.
What we aim to achieve is that, in archunit_suppressions.txt we should put
Method 1 ...
Method 2 ...
Class 1 ...

But in their ignoring violation feature if we specify Method 1.* as a regex whole of the message ie, the block starting with Cycles detected:  will be removed which is not desirable.
So, to treat individual Method 1 ..., Method 2 ... suppressions I have used diff.

replies.bodyText:
you did not answered my question, please do.

meanwhile please move to config/archunit_suppressions.txt, this file is in unmanageable size.

@romani the last answer explains why the archunit_ignore_patterns.txt do not work. I did ask the maintainers. Here's the link TNG/ArchUnit#350

replies.author: gaurabdg

replies.bodyText: @romani Even if we use the feature in the link you mentioned(archunit_ignore_patterns.txt), we do need an UT to check the current violations and tell the user to either fix the new violation or that a exisiting violation has been fixed and needs to be removed from the suppression file, for which we require diff. If we use their feature we have to write all the violations in regex format which is a bit of extra work provided the way I have implemented already satisfies all needs. Please let me know if I am missing something.

replies.bodyText:

from referenced ticket in archunit ...
can we use slices()...should().beFreeOfCycles().ignoreDependency ?
and to make it useful ... we will create test method for each package, so our ignoreXxxxxx will be more specific. So we might be able to resolve dependency one by one and visually see what we still have in ignoreXXXX.
Lets make just another PR to try this.
Lets make one more PR with freeze rule, to see it in action on changes (second commit can remove some dependency by brutal code removal, some will fail but we need to see a diff on store file).

Why do we care that much of dependency of methods on class? I always thought of it as dependency between classes.
can we keep in repo archunit_ignore_patterns.txt as plain text file and do simple string compare by google.truth assert. If diff is happening, conributor just need  to generate new ignore file and send a change on it.

timeline.bodyText:
#7469 (comment)

Checks should not have protected methods or fields.

By the name matching "^(Abstract), isn't this only checking that methods in classes named "Abstract" are not allowed to have protected methods? If that is the case, shouldn't that result in a failure as the whole point of abstract classes is to have protected methods.
Example: 
  
    
      checkstyle/src/main/java/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/coding/AbstractSuperCheck.java
    
    
         Line 55
      in
      2e8c277
    
    
    
    

        
          
           protected abstract String getMethodName(); 
        
    
  


Even for protected methods in final classes, we will have some that are overridden from the super class. Do we need to distinguish between these?

replies.bodyText:
I wrote this condition for the test:
        final ArchRule checkMethodsShouldNotBeProtectedRule =
            methods().that()
            .areNotAnnotatedWith(Override.class).and()
            .areDeclaredInClassesThat()
            .haveSimpleNameEndingWith("Check").and()
            .doNotHaveModifier(JavaModifier.ABSTRACT)
            .should().notBeProtected();

The error reported was as follows:
com.tngtech.archunit.base.ArchUnitException$InvalidSyntaxUsageException: Annotation type java.lang.Override has @Retention(SOURCE), thus the information is gone after compile. So checking this with ArchUnit is useless. 
So, we can't essentially use the Override annotation to skip methods such as processFiltered. I am looking at other workarounds.
replies.author: gaurabdg

replies.bodyText: One thing I can do is to collect all Abstract.* class' methods and generate a regex string like .*(processFiltered | getMethodName...) to add to the archrule condition ..methods().that().haveNameNotMatching(regex) to skip them. Shall I implement this?
